items.title: Error during recording or general usage on Windows 7 (x86, 32-Bit) in ntdll.dll with 0xc0000005
items.body:
Sometimes I get a Memory Error / Stack Overflow exception in Python, sometimes only a "Program is not working any more" in Windows (using python.exe) or nothing using pythonw.exe.

Error is most likely due to usages if CFUNCTYPE instead of WINFUNCTYPE (stdcall for event handlers on x86) (see [windll ctypes call variadic c function from python 2.7 works in win64 but not in win32 (Stack Overflow)](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31379169/setting-up-a-windowshook-in-python-ctypes-windows-api)).

I will create a pull request.

items.title: Keybord.play does not work when called in a function?
items.body:
I am using the keyboard and mouse modules to record user interaction with our software so that we can have some high level GUI tests. 
User input (mouse and keyboard) is recorded and afterwards written in a file so that it can later be replayed to test user interaction with our software. 

Now here comes the weird behavior we are encountering:
#### It only works if I copy'n'paste the content of the functions directly into python. 

Meaning if I copy the content of said `playback` function into a python command line it works as intended and plays the mouse AND keyboard input correctly timed. 
However, if I call this program by using `python record.py playback check.txt` in a command line (or any other scenario per se) then __only__ the mouse movement gets played back correctly. There simply is no keyboard input simulated. 

As an example:
Let's say I have my python file called `record.py`. This python file contains functions `record(..)` and `playback(..)`. When I use said file to record user input everything gets recorded as intended and I receive a file that looks like planned. 

The input file looks as follows:
First line contains a timestamp when the recording started. This is needed to handle the delay between mouse and keyboard recording. 
Second line stores any mouse input.
Every line after that is a keyboard input parsed using the to_json() function from this library.
I have attached an example so that you can see how this file looks. Obviously this would do nonsense on your PC so don't let it run ^^
[check.txt](https://github.com/boppreh/keyboard/files/3560228/check.txt)


It is crucial for us that the keyboard and mouse input gets stored in files and gets played back. When I copy the playback content into python it works exactly as intended. 

### So now my questions:
#### Is there a specific different behavior when running a Python function in comparison to when I copy'n'paste the code into a command line that would cause this behavior?
#### How can i fix this so that a call of `python record.py playback check.txt` behaves as expected and reproduces keyboard input as well?

I am inexpressibly thankful for any help that you can offer me!

Entire source code:
```python
import threading
import mouse
import keyboard

from mouse import ButtonEvent
from mouse import MoveEvent
from mouse import WheelEvent

from keyboard import KeyboardEvent

import time

import json
import sys

def record(file='record.txt'):
    with open(file, 'w+') as f:
        mouse_events = []
        keyboard_events = []
        keyboard.start_recording()
        starttime = time.time()
        mouse.hook(mouse_events.append)
        keyboard.wait('esc')
        keyboard_events = keyboard.stop_recording()
        mouse.unhook(mouse_events.append)
        #first line = start of recording
        #mouse events = second line
        #keyboard events = every remaining line = 1 event
        print(starttime, file=f)
        print(mouse_events, file=f)
        for kevent in range(0, len(keyboard_events)):
            print(keyboard_events[kevent].to_json(), file = f)
        f.close()

def playback(file, speed = 0.5):
    with open(file, 'r') as f:
        #per definition the first line is mouse events and the rest is keyboard events
        lines = f.readlines()
        f.close()
        mouse_events = []
        mouse_events = eval(lines[1])
        keyboard_events = []
        for index in range(2,len(lines)):
            keyboard_events.append(keyboard.KeyboardEvent(**json.loads(lines[index])))
        
        starttime = float(lines[0])
        keyboard_time_interval = keyboard_events[0].time - starttime
        keyboard_time_interval /= speed
        mouse_time_interval = mouse_events[0].time - starttime
        mouse_time_interval /= speed
        #Keyboard threadings:
        k_thread = threading.Thread(target = lambda : time.sleep(keyboard_time_interval) == keyboard.play(keyboard_events, speed_factor=speed))
        #Mouse threadings:
        m_thread = threading.Thread(target = lambda : time.sleep(mouse_time_interval) == mouse.play(mouse_events, speed_factor=speed))
        #start threads
        m_thread.start()
        k_thread.start()
        #waiting for both threadings to be completed
        k_thread.join() 
        m_thread.join()


if __name__ == '__main__':
    if len(sys.argv) > 2 and sys.argv[1] == 'playback':
        playback(sys.argv[2])
    elif len(sys.argv) >= 2 and sys.argv[1] == 'record':
        if(len(sys.argv)) == 3:
            record(sys.argv[2])
        else:
            record()
    else:
        print("missing either 'playback' or 'record' or filename")
```

Meaning when I copy the part starting with `with open(file,'r') as ...` into python it works exactly as intended

items.title: How to quit in the middle of a program with a key press?
items.body:
So I made a simple flashcard app. Basically I run `sudo python flashcards.py -e` for english to spanish, and `sudo python flashcards.py -s` for spanish to english.

I tried to add `keyboard.add_hotkey('q', quit)` to the program to quit when the program detects a press of `q`, but this isn't working.

1) How should I go about exiting the program with a key press of `q`?

2) I'm on mac. Is there a way for me to run this program sudo-less?

```
import argparse
import json
import keyboard
import os
import random
import sys

def load_cards(deck):
    with open(deck) as f:
        return json.load(f)

def read_card(deck):
    keys = [k for k in deck.keys()]
    key = keys[random.randint(0, (len(keys) - 1))]
    print(key.title())
    return key

def flip_card(deck, card):
    print('{}{}'.format(deck[card][0].upper(), deck[card][1:]))

if __name__ == '__main__':
    
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='Spanish flashcard program')

    parser.add_argument('-e', '--english', action='store_false', default=False,
                        help='specifies english to spanish mode')

    parser.add_argument('-s', '--spanish', action='store_false', default=False,
                        help='specifies spanish to english mode')

    if '-e' in sys.argv[1:]:
        deck = load_cards('cards.json')
        deck = dict((v,k) for k,v in deck.items())
        keyboard.add_hotkey('q', quit)
        print('press [SPACE] to advance. press [Q] at anytime to quit the program\n')
        while True:
            card = read_card(deck)
            keyboard.wait('space')
            flip_card(deck, card)
            keyboard.wait('space')
            os.system('clear')

    elif '-s' in sys.argv[1:]:
        deck = load_cards('cards.json')
        keyboard.add_hotkey('q', quit)
        print('press [SPACE] to advance. press [Q] at anytime to quit the program\n')
        while True:
            card = read_card(deck)
            keyboard.wait('space')
            flip_card(deck, card)
            keyboard.wait('space')
            os.system('clear')
```
cards.json (excerpt)
```
{
    "bajar": "to descend",
    "borrar": "to erase",
    "contestar": "to answer",
    "dejar": "to let, allow, leave",
    "desear": "to want, wish",
    "enseñar": "to teach, show",
    "hallar": "to find"
}
```

def start_recording(recorded_events_queue=None, times_list = False):

items.title: add_hotkey keeps bound keys pressed throughout the callback function
items.body:
Hi! Thanks for this lib. I'm using it pretty extensively. 

I nailed down exactly the situations where this bug occurs, and when it doesn't. 
An example for the bug: Given hotkey: 'ctrl+l', sending 'alt' in the callback fn will send ctrl+alt+l, even if 'ctrl+l' was physically released, trigger_on_release is set to True, as so is suppress. 

I checked that via is_pressed. 

1. In the [the attached file](https://github.com/boppreh/keyboard/files/1795140/reproduce.txt) there are 3 main functions (0,1,2) and 4 groups (A,B,C,D) that check those functions from different angles.
2. The functions print whether ctrl is_pressed, with different minor changes between them.
3. The groups add elements like calling the functions in a different thread, sleeping or releasing the hotkey etc.
4. The lines are commented because multiple ones are binding the same hotkey, so please uncomment them as needed.
5. The summary of each group is written inside a tri-quote above it.

Results:
- I tested on the PyPi lib, the master github branch and the suppress branch.
- The master branch and the suppress branch give identical results, so let's refer to them as the repo from now on.
- To bypass the bug, PyPi needs a different thread (call_later), and: either some sleep before checking is_pressed, or a manual keyboard.release. Both are sufficient.
- The repo needs a call_later and a sleep ONLY. Manually releasing doesn't have any effect.

[reproduce.txt](https://github.com/boppreh/keyboard/files/1795140/reproduce.txt)

Hopefully that sheds some light on the issue!

Thanks again,
Gilad

items.title: KeyError 189 for AZERTY keyboards on _send_event - only for key (-)
items.body:
Hey guys, I am making a demo player and trying to make it work with AZERTY keyboards as well as QWERTY.  Basically I made an AZERTY_num_dict for pressing numbers on azerty keyboards, which looks like this:

```Python
azerty_num_dict = {".": "shift+;", "0": "shift+à", "1": "shift+&", "2": "shift+é",
                   "3": "shift+\"", "4": "shift+'", "5": "shift+(", "6": "shift+-",
                   "7": "shift+è", "8": "shift+_", "9": "shift+ç"}
```

So, if the user is using an azerty keyboard- and numbers are needed to be pressed (combo of shift + x on azerty) - they are pressed in this way: 
```python
selection = "Breaking_Dawn_16Feb2018_041619_0markers.rep"

keyboard.write("play ")
for any in str(selection[:-4]):
    if any.isdigit() or any is ".":
        try:
             keyboard.press_and_release(self.azerty_num_dict[any])
        except:
             traceback.print_exc()
    else:
        keyboard.press_and_release(any)
```
My buddy is testing this on an AZERTY keyboard, and every key is working except the number 6.  Here is what he is getting when he tries to play the above selection: 

![demeazerty](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24723883/36643302-8a35314e-1a17-11e8-9d3d-714ab1ca5eba.png)

As you can see - only the 6 's are omitted.  And the error:

![keyerror](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24723883/36643355-01261df4-1a18-11e8-9209-85c0ed4b83c4.png)

So basically: users with AZERTY keyboards get a keyerror when trying to press and release 6 using: ```keyboard.press_and_release("shift+-")```
The error is pertaining to the minus key (-).  Not sure why the keyerror is 189.... the chr() for minus key is 45.  

I reproduced the error on my end by changing my keyboard default language to French (France) and simply trying `keyboard.press_and_release("-")`

![fqilg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24723883/36643536-9efee676-1a1a-11e8-966b-118f03564836.png)


Not sure if this is a possible bug with keyboard package?  Any help would be greatly appreciated I am at a loss for where to go from here.

items.title: keyboard.unhook_all doesn't remove 'suppression' of suppressed hotkeys
items.body:
So if you add hotkeys with `suppress=True` and then call `keyboard.unhook_all()`,
the hotkeys get removed but stay suppressed. (All keyboard events are suppressed for these hotkeys)

I looked at your code for `clear_all_hotkeys()`, which works, and you probably need to add these two lines to `unhook_all()`:

```
    _key_table.suppress_none()
    _hotkeys_suppressed.clear()
```

items.body:
I recently wrote a utility using this library that's meant to integrate with twitch. To try and not interfere with other keybinds, I was using the F13-24 keys with modifiers with a custom keyboard. However, this library seems to not really handle these well at all.

Test:
```python
import keyboard
tests = ["f11", "f12", "shift+f11", "shift+f12"]
for key in tests:

keyboard.wait()
```

Expected result:
Pressing f12 should trigger the f12 hook, pressing shift+f12 triggers the shift+f12 hook
Actual result:

It seems to just trigger the last keybind that was added in further testing. Am I doing something wrong?

items.title: Japanese keyboard layouts cause segfault in _darwinkeyboard.py
items.body:
Line number 126 of _darwinkeyboard.py (current master branch):
```python
# Get keyboard layout
klis = Carbon.TISCopyCurrentKeyboardInputSource()
k_layout = Carbon.TISGetInputSourceProperty(klis, kTISPropertyUnicodeKeyLayoutData)

```
causes a segfault when I try to `import keyboard` on macOS with my input source set to Japanese (in all input modes). It goes away when I try to import with a different input source active (such as Australian, Greek, or Unicode Hex Input).

I wanted to investigate further but I am not familiar with ctypes or the Carbon library, sorry. Thought I'd raise this issue since support for internationalized layouts was mentioned as a goal in #11.
